titlestmt.titleproper: Margaretta (Happy) Fitler Rockefeller papers, Art Files
A Guide to the Margaretta (Happy) Fitler Rockefeller papers, Art Files FA1716

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 18:19:34 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Margaretta (Happy) Fitler Rockefeller papers, Art Files

physdesc.extent: 7 card file boxes (4 x 6) and 5 letter document boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The art files of Margaretta (Happy) Rockefeller document the works of art originally collected by her husband, Nelson A. Rockefeller, and inherited by Happy after his death in 1979. These files are a combination of records on the acquisition, maintenance, display, loan, and (in some cases) disposition of the artworks.
The most significant type of record in this collection is the cohort of art index cards that were created as a catalog of each object or set of objects. They originate from the early 1940s through the 1990s, although the vast bulk predate Governor Rockefeller's death. They were originally incorporated within the set of index cards that are found in the Nelson A. Rockefeller Art Files in FA340. Used as a tool for tracking the collection, the cards were updated either in type or handwriting as the disposition of a piece changedâ€”through sale, gift, or other removal from the collection.

Carol K. Uht and later Cynthia B. Altman were the Rockefellers' curators. They created the cards to record vital information about each artwork for quick access: artist, title, medium, year of creation, dimensions, source of acquisition, year of acquisition, and usually the price paid.

The cards are grouped by cataloguing number, which denotes categories of fine art and objects. The categories include modern art, nonmodern art (which is further broken down by country or region of origin), porcelain, silver, furniture, and decorative art. Each object or set of objects has a two-part number, the first of which refers to the category while the second is a unique identifier. For example, #25-588 is item number 588 of the modern art pieces. Likewise, #11-234 is item number 234 of the nonmodern pieces from Japan.
This collection also includes negatives of both modern and nonmodern pieces, usually organized in the same manner as the card index.
Other records in the collection are sparse and only refer to selected individual works, typically ones that were lent or sold. These files contain inventories, appraisals, insurance valuations, catalogues, loan requests, and some correspondence. Please note that the documentation is not comprehensive in that only a handful of works of art are discussed. Lastly, the collections ends with general content related to properties owned by Happy Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Art Reference Index Cards, Sections 1 through 9: Primitive and Folk Art Overview of Sections

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: To avoid potential confusion, the description and titles of the art cards in Sections 1 through 6 utilize the term "primitive art" when referring to indigenous art works because it was the contemporaneous term used when the Rockefellers collected the pieces and the cataloguing system was established.

did.unittitle: Sotheby's appraisal: "Additional Property"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This small appraisal was included in the second copy of the main Japanese House appraisal from 1992, even though this valuation of pieces of metal, procelain, and pottery was completed in 1982 as an addendum to the original 1979 appraisal of the NAR estate.

did.unittitle: Sotheby's appraisal: Teahouse contents
Sotheby's appraisal: Pocantico Hills Guest House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Likely the contents of the property also known as Hawes Guest House and Harrison House (designed by Wallace Harrison).

did.unittitle: Sotheby's appraisal: 812 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan
Christie's appraisal and sales proposal: Picasso tapestry after Guernica

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Curator Cynthia Altman requested a valuation be done by Christie's of this Picasso tapestry. Christie's produced a sales proposal to put the work up for auction.

did.unittitle: Sotheyby's appraisal: All New York properties

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The appraisal includes 812 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan and the following in Pocantico Hills: Japanese House, Havenwood House, Pool House, Tea House, and Kykuit Main House (fine art only).
